revision.text:
{{Infobox settlement |name = Stranorlar |other_name = {{pad top italic|Srath an Urláir}} |settlement_type = Town |image_skyline = Church- Stranorlar.jpg |image_caption = Stranorlar's Roman Catholic church |pushpin_map = Ireland |pushpin_label_position = right |pushpin_map_caption = Location in Ireland |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] |subdivision_type1 = [[Provinces of Ireland|Province]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Ulster]] |subdivision_type3 = [[Counties of Ireland|County]] |subdivision_name3 = [[County Donegal]] |established_title = |established_date = |unit_pref = Metric |area_footnotes = |area_total_km2 = |population_as_of = |population_footnotes = |population_total = |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone1 = [[West European Time|WET]] |utc_offset1 = +0 |timezone1_DST = [[Irish Standard Time|IST]] ([[Western European Summer Time|WEST]]) |utc_offset1_DST = +1 |coordinates = {{coord|54.8|-7.790|dim:100000_region:IE|format=dms|display=inline,title}} |elevation_footnotes = |elevation_m = 30 |blank_name = [[Irish grid reference system|Irish Grid Reference]] |blank_info = {{iem4ibx|H194946}} |website = {{URL|www.ballybofeystranorlar.com}} |footnotes = }} '''Stranorlar''' ({{Irish place name|Srath an Urláir}}, meaning the "valley of the floor" or flat bottomed valley) is a small town in the [[River Finn (County Donegal)|Finn Valley]] of [[County Donegal]], in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. Stranorlar and [[Ballybofey]] (located on the other side of the [[River Finn (County Donegal)|River Finn]]) form ''the Twin Towns''.
==Transport== The town is located at the junction of the [[N15 road (Ireland)|N15]] and [[N13 road (Ireland)|N13]] [[national primary road]]s. For nearly 100 years, Stranorlar was the headquarters of the [[County Donegal Railways Joint Committee|County Donegal Railway]] system (originally the Finn Valley Railway), with services to [[Derry]] and [[Letterkenny]] via [[Strabane]] (near [[Lifford]]), to [[Ballyshannon]] and [[Killybegs]] via [[Donegal]], and to [[Glenties]]. At its peak the railway had 130 employees. The last train ran from Stranorlar in 1960
[[Stranorlar railway station]] was built by the [[Finn Valley Railway]] and opened on 7 September 1863 and finally closed on 6 February 1960. The old railway station was demolished to make way for a new bus garage owned and run by [[Bus Éireann]]. To celebrate the millennium, the old clock from the railway station was restored and installed in a new clock tower which sits at the old pedestrian entrance to the railway station yard. The town remains the main depot for Bus Éireann within [[County Donegal]].
The nearest railway station is operated by [[Northern Ireland Railways]] and runs from Derry / [[Londonderry railway station]] via [[Coleraine]] to [[Belfast Central railway station]] and [[Belfast Great Victoria Street railway station]]. The strategically important [[Belfast-Derry railway line]] is to be upgraded to facilitate more frequent trains and improvements to the permanent way such as track and signalling to enable faster services.
The next nearest railway station is [[Sligo railway station]] where [[Iarnród Éireann]], [http://www.irishrail.ie Official site - Timetables, bookings and operations] trains run to [[Dublin Connolly]].
==Education== Stranorlar is home to St. Columba's College and Finn Valley College. The town is also home to two primary schools. St Mary's primary school and the Robertson National School.
==Religion== [[File:Church of Ireland Stranorlar - geograph.org.uk - 544386.jpg|thumb|[[Church of Ireland]] in Stranorlar.]] [[Isaac Butt|Isaac Butt MP]], founder of the Home Rule Movement is buried in the churchyard of the [[Church of Ireland]] (C of I Church) which has a registered monument. The Catholic Church of St Mary is an imposing 19th Century structure. There is a [[Reformed Presbyterian Church of Ireland]] and a [[Presbyterian Church of Ireland]] church in Stranorlar also.
==Sport== * [[River Finn (County Donegal)|Finn Valley]] Athletics Club has its track in the town. * There is an 18 hole golf course and game fishing in the river Finn, and nearby is the Lough Alann bird sanctuary. *Stranorlar is home to Finn Valley Rugby Club
==Tourism== [[Drumboe]] Woods are the major attraction of Stranorlar. The woods are managed by [[Coillte]] and provide walking routes along the banks of the River Finn and the upper woods. Outside the town, a small folly called The Steeple is a popular destination for many walkers. From the top of the tower, on a clear day, the hillfort of The Grianan of Aileach can be seen. There is a raised ring fort at Dunwiley, outside the town. There are numerous guest houses throughout the town and on the main street is Stranorlar's only hotel. Kee's Hotel is a family run hotel, first established in the 19th century as a coach house. The vernacular architecture of the town is largely 19th century solid two and three storey townhouses, one or two of some interest. Unfortunately, they are rapidly being lost to development.
==Notable people== * [[Frances Browne]], poet and novelist * [[James Boyle (Donegal politician)|James Boyle]], MP * [[Helen O'Clery]], writer * [[Jason Quigley (boxer)|Jason Quigley]], boxer
==See also== *[[List of towns and villages in the Republic of Ireland|List of towns and villages in Ireland]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Stranorlar}} * [http://www.fiacharts.com/ Local Art Group]
{{County Donegal}}
[[Category:Towns and villages in County Donegal]] [[Category:Twin cities]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Capital Region of Denmark}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Coord|55.66|N|12.4|E|scale:500000|display=title}} '''The Capital Region''' ({{lang-da|Hovedstadsregionen}}) was the administrative name of the [[Municipalities of Denmark|municipalities]] of [[Copenhagen Municipality|Copenhagen]] and [[Frederiksberg Municipality|Frederiksberg]] and the [[Counties of Denmark|counties]] of [[Frederiksborg County|Frederiksborg]], [[Copenhagen County|Copenhagen]], and [[Roskilde County|Roskilde]]. It was replaced by the [[Capital Region of Denmark]] ({{lang-da|Region Hovedstaden}}) as an administrative region on January 1, 2007 as part of the 2007 Danish Municipal Reform. The new region includes the island of Bornholm (in the Baltic Sea 100 nautical miles from Copenhagen), and excludes the southwestern parts of Greater Copenhagen that were covered by Roskilde County. These southwestern areas are instead included in [[Region Zealand]] ({{lang-da|Region Sjælland}}). ==Composition== In 2007 the Capital Region had a population of 1,834,492 and an area of 2,861.41 km² The area consisted of: {| class="wikitable" ! Municipality or County !! Population !! Area
(km²) !! Pop. density
(km²) |-align=right |align=left|[[Copenhagen Municipality]]||503.699||77||6.542 |-align=right |align=left|[[Frederiksberg Municipality]]*||92.234||9||10.516 |-align=right |align=left|[[Copenhagen County]]||618.518||526||1.170 |-align=right |align=left|[[Frederiksborg County]]||378.686||1347||276 |-align=right |align=left|[[Roskilde County]]||241.523||891||265 |-align=right !align=left|Total!!1,834,492!!2,850!!644 |} *Frederiksberg municipality is an enclave surrounded by Copenhagen municipality. [[Copenhagen Zoo]] is located in Frederiksberg municipality, but uses ''Copenhagen'' (Danish, ''København'') in its name. == Today == The same area has (31 December 2012) 1.937.450 inhabitants ( 680 inhabitants/km²) However the Capital Region has been expanded and [[Stevns Municipality]] has been added. That area is 3030 km² and has 1.957.611 inhabitants ( 646 inhabitants/km²) The Capital Region is still in use at several levels: * Local public traffic, ticket fare zones (Metro, S-train, Local trains, Regional trains within the area, busses etc.) * Television - three regional TV-channels broadcast over the entire area * The area is a region for ''Vejdirektoratet'', the Danish motorway & road maintenance authority * It's also a region of the Danish national rail, [[DSB (railway company)|DSB]]. If f.i. buying a ticket in [[Jutland]], the ticket is valid for any station within the Capital Region. * Public identification, people that lives within its boundaries usually identify themselves as inhabitants of the Capital Region. == References == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121215110433/http://www2.sns.dk/udgivelser/2007/978-87-7279-780-9/html/bred07.htm Map showing the extent of ''Hovedstadsregionen'' including the extension of Stevns municipality (far Southernmost part)] [[Category:Metropolitan areas of Denmark|Copenhagen]] [[Category:Geography of Denmark|Capital Region]] [[Category:Geography of Copenhagen]]

revision.text:
{{About|the river in the Czech Republic|the symphonic poem|Má vlast|the restaurant in Helsinki, Finland|Vltava (restaurant)}} {{Infobox river | name = Vltava | name_native = | name_native_lang = | name_other = | name_etymology = <!---------------------- IMAGE & MAP --> | image = Prague skyline view.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Vltava in Prague | map = {{superimpose|align=center|width=275px | base = Czechia - background map.png | float = Vltava River (CZE) - location and watershed.svg }} | map_size = | map_caption = The course and [[drainage basin]] of the Vltava from its source to its confluence with the Elbe (magenta) | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_size = | pushpin_map_caption= <!---------------------- LOCATION --> | subdivision_type1 = Country | subdivision_name1 = [[Czech Republic]] | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name2 = | subdivision_type3 = Region | subdivision_name3 = [[South Bohemian Region|South Bohemia]], [[Central Bohemian Region|Central Bohemia]] | subdivision_type4 = | subdivision_name4 = | subdivision_type5 = Cities | subdivision_name5 = [[Český Krumlov]], [[České Budějovice]], [[Prague]] <!---------------------- PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS --> | length = {{convert|430|km|mi|abbr=on}} | width_min = | width_avg = | width_max = | depth_min = | depth_avg = | depth_max = | discharge1_location= | discharge1_min = | discharge1_avg = {{convert|149.9|m3/s|cuft/s|abbr=on}} | discharge1_max = <!---------------------- BASIN FEATURES --> | source1 = {{Interlanguage link multi|Teplá Vltava|cs|3=Teplá Vltava|lt=Černý potok}} | source1_location = [[Černá hora (Šumava)|Černá hora]], [[Bohemian Forest]] | source1_coordinates= {{coord|48|58|29|N|13|33|39|E|display=inline}} | source1_elevation = {{convert|1172|m|abbr=on}} | mouth = [[Elbe]] | mouth_location = [[Mělník]] | mouth_coordinates = {{coord|50|20|29|N|14|28|30|E|display=inline,title}} | mouth_elevation = {{convert|155|m|abbr=on}} | progression = | river_system = | basin_size = {{convert|28090|km2|abbr=on}} | tributaries_left = [[Otava (river)|Otava]], [[Berounka]] | tributaries_right = [[Lužnice (river)|Lužnice]], [[Sázava (river)|Sázava]] | custom_label = | custom_data = | extra = }}
The '''Vltava''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|v|ʊ|l|t|ə|v|ə}};<ref>{{citation|last=Wells|first=John C.|year=2008|title=Longman Pronunciation Dictionary|edition=3rd|publisher=Longman|isbn=9781405881180}}</ref> {{IPA-cs|ˈvl̩tava|-|Cs-Vltava.ogg}}; {{lang-de|Moldau}}, {{IPA-de|ˈmɔldaʊ|IPA}}) is the longest [[river]] within the [[Czech Republic]], running southeast along the [[Bohemian Forest]] and then north across [[Bohemia]], through [[Český Krumlov]], [[České Budějovice]] and [[Prague]], and finally merging with the [[Elbe]] at [[Mělník]]. It is commonly referred to as the "Bohemian sea" and the "[[Czech people|Czech]] national river".{{cn|date=December 2017}}
==Course== The Vltava river is {{convert|430.3|km}} long and drains an area {{convert|28,090|km2}} in size, over half of Bohemia and about a third of the Czech Republic's entire territory.{{GeoQuelle|DE-BY|GV}}<ref name=ceskyKrumlovInfo>{{cite web|title=The Vltava River – Historical Communication Link in the Český Krumlov Region|url=http://www.ckrumlov.info/docs/en/region_histor_vltava.xml|website=Český Krumlov – UNESCO World Heritage|accessdate=19 June 2015|quote=The length of its flow to the mouth of the river to the Labe river near Mělnik is 430.2 km. Down to Český Krumlov it has a catchment area of 1,339 km2, the whole basin of the Vltava river is 28,090 km2.}}</ref> As it runs through Prague, the river is crossed by 18 [[bridge]]s (including the [[Charles Bridge]]) and covers {{convert|31|km}} within the city.<ref>[http://www.avantgarde-prague.com/prague-guide/prague-and-the-czech-republic/the-city-of-prague/ Source : Avantgarde Prague ]</ref> The water from the river was used for drinking until 1912, when the [[Vinohrady Water Tower]] ceased pumping operations.<ref name=stove>[http://stovezata.praha.eu/en-water-tower-of-vinohrady.html Water Tower of Vinohrady], stovezata.praha.eu, retrieved 14 November 2013</ref> It is, however, the source of drinking water in case of failures/repairs to the water supply from the Želivka and Kárané sources. The Podolí water processing plant is on standby for such cases with the long section of the river upstream of the Podolí plant under the stricter, second degree of pollution prevention regulations.
Several [[dam]]s were built on it in the 1950s. The [[Orlík Dam]] supports the largest reservoir on the Vltava by volume, while the [[Lipno Dam]] in the Bohemian Forest ({{lang-cz|Šumava}}) retains the largest reservoir by area. North of Prague the [[Štěchovice Reservoir]] has been built over the site of the [[St John's Rapids]]. The river also features numerous [[Lock (water transport)|locks]] and [[weirs]] that help mitigate its flow from {{convert|1172|m}} in elevation at its source near the German border to {{convert|155|m}} at its mouth in Mělník.
The height difference from source to mouth is about {{convert|1016|m}} and the largest stream at the source is named Černý Potok (Black Brook, AKA Teplá Vltava). The Vltava itself originates by a confluence of two streams, the Warm Vltava (''{{Interlanguage link multi|Teplá Vltava|cs}}''), which is longer, and the Cold Vltava (''[[Kalte Moldau|Studená Vltava]]''), sourcing in [[Bavaria]]. Along its course, Vltava receives many tributaries, the biggest being [[Otava (river)|Otava]] and [[Berounka]] from the left and [[Lužnice (river)|Lužnice]] and [[Sázava River|Sázava]] from the right side. Its section around [[Český Krumlov]] (specifically from [[Vyšší Brod]] to [[Boršov nad Vltavou]]) is a very popular destination of [[water tourism]].
==Etymology== [[File:Historic Centre of Český Krumlov-111740.jpg|thumb|Historic Centre of [[Český Krumlov]] near Vltava river.]] Both the Czech name ''{{lang|cs|Vltava}}'' and the German name ''{{lang|de|Moldau}}'' are believed to originate from the [[Proto-Germanic|old Germanic]] words ''{{lang|gem-x-proto|wilt ahwa}}'' ("wild water"; compare [[Latin]] ''{{lang|la|aqua}}'').<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Šmilauer |first1=Vladimír |title=O jménech našich řek |trans-title=Names of our rivers |work=Naše řeč |volume=30 |issue=9–10 |pages=161–165 |publisher=[[Institute of the Czech Language]] |year=1946 |url=http://nase-rec.ujc.cas.cz/archiv.php?art=3983 |issn=0027-8203 |language=Czech}}</ref> In ''{{lang|la|[[Annales Fuldenses]]}}'' (872 AD) it is called ''{{lang|la|Fuldaha}}''; from 1113 AD it is attested as ''{{lang|zlw|Wultha}}''. In ''{{lang|la|[[Chronica Boemorum]]}}'' (1125 AD) it is attested for the first time in its [[Czech language|Bohemian]] form as ''{{lang|cs|Wlitaua}}''.<ref name=ceskyKrumlovInfo/>
On the other side there is a river ''{{lang|uk-Latn|Ltava}}'' in Ukraine with no traces of Germanic origins. The name of a settlement on this river was mentioned in the [[Hypatian Chronicle]] in 1174, traditionally connected to the name of the city of [[Poltava]], [[Ukraine]]. There are many theories describing etymology of ''Ltava''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.unian.ua/politics/223820-vidkrittya-profesora-tischenka-nashi-predki-znali-zaratustru.html |title=Відкриття професора Тищенка: наші предки знали Заратустру |trans-title=Discovery by Professor Tishchenko: our ancestors knew Zarathustra |first=Володимир |last=Ільченко |publisher=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency]] |date=21 May 2009 |accessdate= |language=uk }}</ref>
==Floods== The Vltava basin has flooded multiple times throughout recorded history. Markers have been created along the banks denoting the water line for notable floods in 1784, 1845, 1890, 1940, and the highest of all in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Papadaniil|first1=Sofia|last2=Schütze|first2=Susann|last3=Alukwe|first3=Isaac|title=I. Flood Protection Measures of the City of Prague|url=http://intranet.floodmaster.de/wiki/Sunday_16_September|website=Technische Universitat Dresden|accessdate=19 June 2015|date=16 September 2007|quote=Several flood marks along the river show the water levels of the different events in history and try to keep this danger of flooding in mind of the people.}}</ref><ref name=floodingInPrague>{{cite web|last1=Yates|first1=Ricky|title=Flooding in Prague|url=http://rickyyates.com/flooding-in-prague/|website=Ricky Yates – an Anglican in Prague|accessdate=19 June 2015|date=9 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Yates|first1=Ricky|title=The Vltava River|url=http://rickyyates.com/the-vltava-river/|website=Ricky Yates – an Anglican in Prague|accessdate=19 June 2015|date=15 April 2012}}</ref>
In August of that year, the basin was heavily affected by the [[2002 European floods]] when the flooded river killed several people and caused massive damage and disruption along its length, including in Prague. It left the oldest bridge in Prague, Charles Bridge, seriously weakened, requiring years of work to repair.<ref name="floodingInPrague"/>
Prague was again [[2013 European floods#Vltava river|flooded in 2013]]. Many locations within the Vltava and Elbe basins were left under water, including the [[Prague Zoo]], but metal barriers were erected along the banks of the Vltava to help protect the historic city centre.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bond|first1=Anthony|title=Prague under water as floods claim ELEVEN lives across Europe and threaten German city of Dresden|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2335696/Prague-water-floods-claim-ELEVEN-lives-Europe-threaten-German-city-Dresden.html|accessdate=19 June 2015|work=Daily Mail|date=4 June 2013|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130607115315/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2335696/Prague-water-floods-claim-ELEVEN-lives-Europe-threaten-German-city-Dresden.html |archivedate=7 June 2013|deadurl=no|quote=Areas to the south and north of the Czech capital were submerged, including the city's zoo and horse racing track, in the worst flooding in a decade which followed days of heavy rain. But metal barriers erected along the Vltava river banks protected the historical city centre.}}</ref> {{wide image|Panorama-prag-metronom2.jpg|900px|The Vltava as it flows along the north side of central Prague, taken from the [[Stalin Monument (Prague)|Stalin Monument]] in [[Letná Park]]|95%|center|alt=Panoramic view of the river}} ==Dams== Nine hydroelectric dams have been built on the Vltava to regulate the water flow and generate [[hydroelectric power]]. Beginning at the headwaters, these are: [[Lipno Dam|Lipno]], [[Lipno II Dam|Lipno II]], [[Hněvkovice Dam|Hněvkovice]], [[Kořensko Dam|Kořensko]], [[Orlík Dam|Orlík]], [[Kamýk Dam|Kamýk]], [[Slapy Dam|Slapy]], [[Štěchovice Reservoir|Štěchovice]] and [[Vrané Dam|Vrané]].
==References in culture and science== One of the best-known works of [[classical music]] by a Czech composer is [[Bedřich Smetana]]'s ''[[Má vlast#Vltava|Vltava]]'', usually called ''The Moldau'' in English. It is from the [[Romantic music|Romantic era]] of classical music and is a musical description of the river's course through Bohemia ([https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kdtLuyWuPDs listen]).
A [[minor planet]] [[2123 Vltava]] discovered in 1973 by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] astronomer [[Nikolai Stepanovich Chernykh]] is named after the river.<ref>{{cite book | last = Schmadel | first = Lutz D. | coauthors = | title = Dictionary of Minor Planet Names | page = 172 | edition = 5th | year = 2003 | publisher = Springer Verlag | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?q=2123+Vltava+1973 | isbn = 3-540-00238-3 | accessdate = 2009-10-09}}</ref>
Smetana's symphonic poem also inspired a song of the same name by [[Bertolt Brecht]]. An English version of it, by [[John Willett]], features the lyrics ''Deep down in the Moldau the pebbles are shifting'' / ''In Prague three dead emperors moulder away.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.antiwarsongs.org/canzone.php?lang=en&id=5159#agg117930 |title=The song of the Moldau |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=21 August 2012 |website=Anti War Songs |accessdate=25 September 2013}}</ref>
